journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit

title-group.article-title: High-speed maglev train-guideway–tunnel–soil modelling of ground vibration

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Lab of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China
2School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Lab of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China. email: jxlong@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: A fully coupled three-dimensional multi-body finite element model coupled with a perfect matching layer approach is presented to study the ground vibrations created by a high-speed maglev train running in a tunnel. The maglev train is assumed to consist of multiple rigid bodies and the magnetic force between the maglev train and its guideway is simulated using linear springs and dampers. The guideway, tunnel and soil are modeled by three dimensional finite elements with PML as the artificial boundary condition. The results obtained for a maglev train running on a viaduct line show a reasonable agreement with available experimental data, which demonstrates the validity of the proposed model. This model is subsequently utilized to simulate the vibration levels created by the train running in a tunnel in terms of parameters related to the maglev train, tunnel, and soil.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Maglev trains are based on the concept of non-contact magnetic levitation and as such they have numerous advantages when compared with traditional trains including: a higher speed, lower pollution levels, lower energy consumption levels, higher passenger capacity, etc. [1]. A 30-km long maglev line that links Pudong International Airport and Longyang Road Metro Station in Shanghai has been in operation since 2003. The maglev train moves over viaducts with pile foundations and a maximum operation speed of 430 km/h can be reached. The widespread adoption of maglev technology will inevitably require that maglev lines pass through densely populated urban areas which will require the lines to run in tunnels. Therefore, the vibration created by the operation of a high-speed maglev train in the confined space of a tunnel is a subject that requires investigation.

There is an extensive literature on maglev technology that is mainly focused on the dynamic interaction between a maglev train and the guideway system. Hägele and Dignath [2] have simulated a complete maglev vehicle moving along a guideway consisting of several girders. Lee et al. [3] performed a study on the effect of vehicle and guideway characteristics on the dynamic responses of low and medium-speed maglev systems. Ren et al. [4] developed a numerical model to investigate the dynamic characteristics of the guideway and the vehicle‐guideway interaction. However, none of these studies considered the vibrations induced in a tunnel's soil system.

In comparison the ground vibration generated by traditional trains running in tunnels has been widely studied; numerical methods proving to be an effective tool in this case. Most of the simulation studies reported in the literature have been based on two-dimensional models; however, increased computing power has lead to the adoption of two-and-a-half dimensional (2.5D) and three-dimensional (3D) models. For example, Yang et al. [5] studied the vibration effects created by trains moving in tunnels using a 2.5D finite/infinite element approach. Sheng et al. [6] studied ground-born vibration using the wavenumber finite/boundary element method. The vibration effects created by operating a train in a variety oftunnel structures have been studied using a coupled periodic finite element‐boundary element (FE‐BE) model in [7–10]. Andersen and Jones [11] studied the vibration transmission from the tunnel to the ground using a coupled FE‐BE scheme. Inthese studies, the finite element method was shown to be an effective method; the artificial boundary condition, boundary element, and infinite element are typical approaches to perform simulations in the infinite domain.

In this paper, a fully coupled 3D multi-body finite element‐perfect match layer model is presented for the prediction of the vibrations induced by a high-speed maglev train running in a tunnel. To validate the methodology and dynamic coupling model, the computed results for a maglev train running on a viaduct line is compared to experimental data obtained on viaduct lines. The creation of vibration effects created by running a maglev train in a tunnel is studied in simulation studies that consider the variation ofparameters related to the maglev train, tunnel, and soil.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 illustrates the numerical methods and section 3 introduces the 3D model of the train‐guideway‐tunnel‐soil system. Section 4 verifies the methodology and dynamic coupling model and section 5 discusses the interaction force between the maglev train and the guideway girder. Section 6 presents the effects of the maglev train, tunnel, and soil parameters on the dynamic response of the tunnel and ground. Conclusions are drawn in section 7.

sec.title: 2.1 Dynamic finite element method
sec.p: The finite element method has proved to be an effective method to analyse the vibration effects created by a train running in a tunnel. The momentum equations are solved both in the spatial domain and the time domain in the finite element approach. In the spatial domain, the non-linear dynamic finite element equation is given by (1) where M and C are the mass and damping matrices, respectively, Fint and Fext are the internal and external force vectors, respectively, X· and X·· are the nodal velocity and acceleration vectors, respectively.

In the time domain, the solution of equation (1) is obtained using the explicit central difference scheme, in which the accelerations, velocities, and displacements in every time step are updated as follows [12] (2) where Δtn = tn+1 - tn and Δtn-1 = tn - tn-1 are time intervals.

Compared with implicit schemes, the use of a lumped-mass matrix means that the explicit integration scheme requires less memory and is less time-consuming. However, the central difference method is conditionally stable, which requires that the time step should be less than the critical time step, which can be represented as (3) where e indicates the elements of the model, le is the characteristic length of the element, and ce is the wave speed in that element.

sec.title: 2.2 Rigid-body representation in the finite element method
sec.p: The dynamic equations for a rigid body are given by. (4) where M is the diagonal mass matrix, J is the inertial tensor, Xcm is the location of the centre of mass, ω is the angular velocity of the body, eijk is the Levi‐Civita permutation tensor, Fx, Fω are the generalized forces and torques, respectively, and i,j,k indicates components.

A rigid body is created in the finite element method by specifying that all the elements in a mesh are rigid. The central issues associated with implementing equation (1) include the following [13].
Calculating M and J. The mass and inertial tensor of a rigid body (RB) are calculated by performing the following summation. (5) (6) where the subscript α indicates the node that is associated with the elements in the rigid body, mα is the mass, x¯αi=xαi-Xi cm, xαi is the coordinate of node α and the subscript i indicates the component.
Calculating Fx and Fω. The forces and torques are found by summing over the nodes (7) (8) where fα is the summed force for node α, the subscripts i and k indicate the components. The summations account for all of the forces.
Update displacements, velocities, and inertial tensor of the rigid body. The displacement of the rigid body is measured from the initialized location of the centre of mass and it is calculated using (9) The initial velocities of the nodes for the rigid body are calculated using (10) where A is the transformation from the rotated reference configuration to the global coordinate frame, θ is the rotation of the body, and ω is the angular velocity of the body in the global coordinate frame. At the initial time, A is the identity transformation, and the reference configuration is assumed to be co-aligned with the global reference frame.

After calculating the accelerations for the rigid body using equation (4), the velocities are updated as described in section 2.1. The inertial tensor must be transformed each time step based on the incremental rotations (11) The coordinates and velocities of the nodes of the rigid body are updated as (12) (13) where x¯(tn)=x(tn)-Xcm(tn).

sec.title: 2.3 The artificial boundary layer
sec.p:
An artificial boundary is needed when using the finite element method to simulate wave propagation problems in an unbounded domain. A perfect match layer (PML) is a wave-absorbing layer that is placed adjacent to a truncated model of an infinite domain, asshown in Fig. 1. Applying a suitable form of thecoordinate stretching function to the elastic wave equation allows the PML to perfectly attenuate outgoing waves and then reflect them with arbitrarily small amplitudes back to the truncated domain. [14, 15] Fig. 1
PML artificial boundary

Let the 3D space be defined by the coordinate system {xi} with the orthonormal basis {ei}. The PML is defined by the coordinate system {xi '} withthe orthonormal basis{ei '}. The two bases are related by the basis rotation matrix Q, with components Qij:=ei·ej '. Harmonic time dependence of thedisplacement, stress, and strain, e.g. u(x,t)=u¯(x)exp(iωt), exists in the three dimensions. Applying a mutually independent non-zero, continuous, complex-valued stretching function λi to each of the coordinates{xi '}, as well as the coordinate transformation, the governing frequency-domain equations for a PML in the basis {ei} can be obtained [16] as (14) where Λ=QΛ'QT and Λ'=diag[1/λ1(x1 '),1/λ2(x2 '),1/λ3(x3 ')].

The stretching function is assumed to have the form (no summation) [17] (15) where cs is the shear wave speed and L is the characteristic length of the system; a convenient choice for L is the depth of the PML. The functions and are attenuation functions served to attenuate evanescent waves and propagating waves, respectively. Substituting equation (15) into equation (14) and applying the inverse Fourier transform to the result leads to the time-domain equations for the 3D elastic PML.

The attenuation functions in the PML are chosen as fi e=fi p=fi, with [18] (16) where xi is the distance into the PML, and LPi is the depth of the PML, represented by the number of elements nPi through the depth.

sec.title: 3.1 Model of a high-speed maglev train
sec.p:
A four-section maglev train model was created based on the TR08 maglev system. Each section of the train consisted of the train body, levitation bogies, levitation guidance, and brake magnets, and the primary and secondary suspensions. The model of one section of the maglev train is shown in Fig. 2. The levitation bogies beneath the train body were designed to support the electromagnet and to transmit vertical, lateral, traction, and braking forces, which consisted of two levitation frames and a longitudinal beam structure used to connect them. The levitation magnets were connected to the levitation frame by springs (primary suspension) on each side of the train with relative vertical flexibility. The levitation bogies and train body were connected via traction rods in the longitudinal direction and a pendulum design including air springs, elastic rubber stacks, etc., in the section plane (secondary suspension) [19]. The train body, levitation bogies, and levitation magnets were assumed to be rigid bodies with two degrees of freedom consisting of vertical and pitch movements. The primary and secondary suspensions were represented by vertical spring and damper elements. Since only vertical motions were considered in this study, the guidance magnet was neglected and therefore, each section of the maglev train was regarded as a 38-degree-of-freedom dynamic system. The parameters of the maglev train are listed in Table 1. Fig. 2
Maglev train model (a) elevation view and (b) section view Table 1
Parameters of maglev train
Parameter Value
Weight of vehicle body (kg) 39 000
Pitch inertia of vehicle body (kg•m2) 1.755 × 106
Weight of levitation bogie (kg) 660
Pitch inertia of levitation bogie (kg•m2) 550
Weight of levitation magnet (kg) 603
Pitch inertia of levitation magnet (kg•m2) 434
Stiffness of primary suspension (N/m) 2.0 × 107
Damping of primary suspension (N•s/m) 5000
Stiffness of secondary suspension (N/m) 3.9 × 105
Damping of secondary suspension (N•s/m) 7000

Movement of the maglev train was created by defining a constant velocity boundary condition along the longitudinal direction. The gravitational force acting on the maglev train was considered in the body forces.

sec.title: 3.2 Model of the guideway‐tunnel‐soil model
sec.p:
In this study the guideway of the maglev system was taken to consist of π-shaped support girders with a span length of 12.384 m. The tunnel lining was formed from precast concrete segments and joined with bolts in the circumferential and longitudinal directions this allowed the tunnel to be considered to be a continuous structure. A cross-sectional view of the tunnel and guideway and their key dimensions are shown in Fig. 3. The material properties for the guideway, track support structures, and tunnel lining were: density 2500 kg/m3, Poisson's ratio 0.2, damping ratio 0.006, and an elastic modulus of 36.0 GPa for the guideway, 32.5 GPa for the track support structures, and 35.5 GPa for the tunnel lining. Fig. 3
Cross-sectional view of the guideway and tunnel

The inherent symmetry of the system meant that only half of the guideway‐tunnel‐ground system had to be modelled. The model had dimensions of a 300 m length, 60 m width, and 50 m depth; the tunnel lining was modelled using thick shells to support the bending moment and the other structures were modelled using solid elements. The depth of the tunnel at its centre was taken to be 20 m. Figure 4 shows the finite element model of the guideway‐tunnel‐soil system. Fig. 4
Model of the guideway–tunnel–ground system (a) detailed view and (b) whole view

The soil was considered to be formed by horizontally layered soil with the material properties listed in Table 2. The finite element sizes of the six soil layers were approximately 0.39, 0.43, 0.48, 0.59, 0.73, and 0.80 m, which were determined as one-sixth of the shear wavelength for a frequency of 80 Hz. The parameters of the attenuation function in the PML were chosen to be f0 = 9.8, p = 2, and np = 5 for absorbing outgoing waves [18]. The mesh size of the PML was the same as that for the adjacent soil element. Table 2
Material parameters of soil
Layer Thickness (m) Density (kg/m3) Elastic modulus (MPa) Poisson's ratio Damping ratio
1 3.4 1760 158.5 0.33 0.03
2 5.1 1800 201.7 0.35 0.03
3 8 1820 245.8 0.32 0.03
4 5 1850 378.1 0.38 0.03
5 15.5 1900 607.2 0.4 0.03
6 13 1920 711.6 0.4 0.03

sec.title: 3.3 Model of the interactive electromagnetic force
sec.p:
The problem of creating a model for the electromagnetic force was first studied by Popp [20]. Referring toFig. 5, the magnetic levitation force can be writtenas (17) The circuit equation can be written as (18) where μ0 is the magnetic permeability, N is the number of turns in the magnet winding, A is the pole face area, i(t) is the electric circuit, c(t) represents the magnetic air gap, u(t) is the input voltage tothe magnet, and R is the total resistance of the electrical components. Fig. 5
Principle of magnetic suspension

The magnetic force is a non-linear function that is dependent on the air gap and its derivative, and also the current or voltage in the coils. Considering the 10 mm air gap and its small variance in the high-speed maglev system, a sufficiently accurate magnetic force can be created by its linearization at the balance point [21], which can be expressed as (19) where F is the electromagnetic force, F0 is the static magnetic force at the balance point, Kp and Cp are the equivalent magnetic stiffness and damping, respectively, c is the air gap, and c0 is the air gap at the balance point. The total equivalent magnetic stiffness and damping of a single magnet were chosen to be 25.98 Ns/mm and 0.14 kN/mm, respectively [2].

In maglev systems the magnetic forces are evenly distributed along the total train length. In this study, this was achieved using a series of springs and dampers, as shown in Fig. 6. One end of these springs and dampers was connected to the magnets, and the other end was constrained to be in the direction normal to the guideway surface, however, some movement can also occur along the direction tangential to the surface with no friction. Fig. 6
Model of the magnetic force

sec.title: 3.4 Guideway irregularity
sec.p:
The irregularity model adopted in this paper was first proposed by Tsunashima and Abe [22] and is shown in Fig. 7. The irregularities are divided into three sections based on the wavelength: less than 3 m, 3–60 m, and above 60 m. Fig. 7
Power spectral density of guideway irregularity

The irregularity was simulated by the wave superposition method using the equation (20) where S(ω) is the power spectral density (PSD) of the irregularity, N is the number of divided frequencies within the considered frequency bandwidth, Δω is the frequency interval, and ϕ represents independent random variables that are uniformly distributed from zero to 2π.

sec.title: 4 VERIFICATION OF THE MODEL
sec.p: Since currently no maglev train runs in a tunnel, it is not possible to validate the results obtained in simulation studies using the proposed models by comparing them to experimentally obtained data. However, viaduct lines for maglev trains have been in operation for several years and several field measurements on the one-third octave band spectra of the velocity have been reported. Thus, the situation of a maglev train running on a viaduct line was simulated and the obtained results compared with the available experimental data to validate the proposed methodology

The maglev train, electromagnetic force, guideway irregularity, and PML boundary models used in the simulations were those described in section 2; only the maglev line model changed. The existing operational maglev lines consist of viaduct and pile foundations. The piles, pile caps, piers, bent caps and guideway that constitute the maglev line are shown in Fig. 8. The guideway is supported on the bent caps, which have a different cross-section and span length to those used in tunnels. The space of two adjacent bridge foundations is 25 m. Fig. 8
Geometry and dimensions of the maglev viaduct line

Figure 9 shows the model of the maglev viaduct line. The model had dimensions of a 290 m length, 70 m width, and 50 m depth. The pile was modelled by beams and other structures were modelled using solid elements. The considered maglev train speed was 400 km/h. The material properties for the maglev line were taken to be: density ρ = 2500 kg/m3, Poisson's ratio ν = 0.2, damping ratio ξ = 0.006, an elastic modulus of 36.0 GPa for the guideway, 34.0 GPa for the bent cap, and 32.5 GPa for the pier, pile cap, and pile. The soil properties were taken to be those described in section 3.4. Fig. 9
Model of the maglev viaduct line (a) detailed view and (b) whole view

Figure 10 compares the computed and experimentally determined one-third octave band spectra for vertical velocities on the surface of the ground. The reference velocity is 10−8 m/s. The computed results show a reasonable agreement with the experimental data, which demonstrates the applicability of the proposed methodology. The major discrepancies occur under 2 Hz and above 40 Hz. These discrepancies can be attributed to the simplifications made in deriving the models e.g. omitting the details of the levitation magnet and guideway and possible inaccuracies in the used material parameters. Fig. 10
Comparison of ground response obtained in experiment studies and numerical simulations for maglev train on a viaduct (a) 0 m away from the pile cap and (b) 30 m away from the pile cap

sec.title: 5 INTERACTION FORCES
sec.p:
Since the methodology and models described in sections 2 and 3 have been validated they are now used to study the vibrations induced by a high-speed maglev train running in a tunnel. The interaction forces are presented and discussed in this section. Figures 11 shows the forces at the mid-point of the guideway girder (interaction between the maglev train and guideway) at different train speeds. Fig. 11
Interactive forces at the mid-point of the guideway girder (a) in the time domain and (b) in the frequency domain

As can be seen from Fig. 11(a), the forces have a general trend of a rectangular pulse that contains fluctuations. Since the levitation magnets are located on both sides along the entire length of the train in a maglev system, the magnetic forces between the guideway and the maglev train are distributed evenly over the length of the maglev train. Therefore, the forces caused by the maglev train show the general trend of a rectangular pulse. The fluctuations in the forces are mainly caused by irregularities in the guideway. This is different from the situation observed for traditional trains, in which the loads are distributed at the wheels and are thus unevenly distributed over the length of the train. The average forces are only weakly influenced by the speed of the train. However, the extent of the fluctuations in the forces does show a significant correlation with increase in the speed of the train.

As can be seen from Fig. 11(b), the frequency of the interaction forces is generally less than10 Hz with the maximum response occurring at a frequency of 0 Hz. This is a result of the rectangular shape of the force pulse. The result obtained by applying a fast Fourier transform (FFT) to the fluctuating section of the forces is shown in Fig. 12 Higher frequency contents can be seen compared to the case of the rectangle pulse. The frequency content shows a tread of having higher frequency components as the speed of the train increases. Fig. 12
Fluctuations in the interactive forces

sec.title: 6 VIBRATION RESPONSES
sec.p: A parametric study was performed to identify the parameters that influence the vibration level created by a maglev train running in a tunnel at a speed of 300 km/h. The reference model was described in section 3. The vibration level was considered in terms of the one-third octave band whose calculation involved the following steps:
Step 1: select the velocity record, analyse it using a FFT, and calculate the PSD function.
Step 2: calculate the effective velocity of all one-third octave bands.

Step 3: calculate the overall vibration level by summing the individual vibrations (21) where (22) and vref is the reference velocity which is equal to 10−8 m/s, vrms(fc) is the effective root mean square velocity of the one-third octave bands, and fc is the centre frequency.

sec.title: 6.1 Effect of the speed of the maglev train
sec.p: The influence of the speed of the maglev train was considered at three speeds: 250, 300 (reference case), and 350 km/h. These values are smaller than the operation speed of 420 km/h for a maglev train running on open track but are realistic values for operation in a tunnel.

Figures 13 shows the velocity at the surface of the ground as a function of frequency for the considered train speeds. From this figure it is clear that an increase in speed is accompanied by an increase in the vibration level and that the vibration contains higher frequency components. These higher frequency components attenuate faster than lower frequency components with an increase in distance from the tunnel axis, which means that the frequency content shifts towards lower frequencies as the distance from the tunnel axis increases. The difference in the ground vibration obtained for the considered cases also becomes smaller as the distance from the tunnel axis increases. Fig. 13
Velocity at the surface of the ground as a function of speed of the maglev train speed at distances of (a) 0 m, (b) 20 m, and (c) 40 m away from the axis of the tunnel

The vibration levels in the tunnel and on the ground are shown in Fig. 14. The higher the speed then the higher the vibration level both in the tunnel and on the surface of the ground. The vibration attenuates significantly between the mid-point of the girder and the support, whereas it only decreases by a small amount in being transferred between the girder support and the tunnel because of the rigid connection between these two features. An elastic rubber pad could be added between the girder support and the tunnel floor to create further vibration attenuation. A difference of between 3 and 5 dB in the vibration levels at small lateral distances from the tunnel axis is observed to be created by a 50 km/h variation in the train speed. Fig. 14
Comparison of the vibration level due variation of the speed of the maglev train (a) in the tunnel and (b) at the surface of the ground

sec.title: 6.2 Effect of the thickness of the tunnel lining
sec.p:
The effect of the thickness of the tunnel lining was considered at three valves: 0.4, 0.6 (reference case), and 0.8 m. Figure 15 compares the vibration levels created at the three considered thickness values. It is clear from these figures that the thickness of the tunnel lining has a negligible effect on the vibration levels in the tunnel and on the surface of the ground. This finding has previously been reported in [5] and [9]. Fig. 15
Comparison of the vibration level due to variation of the thickness of the tunnel lining (a) in the tunnel and (b) at the surface of the ground

sec.title: 6.3 Effect of soil stiffness
sec.p:
In order to investigate the effect of the stiffness of the soil a ± 50 per cent variation in the elastic modulus of all soil layers in the reference model was imposed to make the soil either softer or stiffer. The effect of the soil stiffness on the observed vibration characteristics are shown in Fig. 16. The vibration level observed for the ground is sensitive to a deviation in the soil stiffness. In this study, the 50 per cent decrease in the elastic modulus resulted in about a 6 dB increase in the vibration level at the surface of the ground, whereas a 50 per cent increase in elastic modulus resulted in a 4 dB decrease in the vibration level. In the tunnel, all observation points are also sensitive to the value of the elastic modulus except for the mid-point of the girder. Fig. 16
Comparison of the vibration level due to variation in the soil stiffness (a) in the tunnel and (b) at the surface of the ground

sec.title: 6.4Effect of soil damping ratio
sec.p: The influence of the soil damping ratio was also studied. The soil damping ratio was assumed to be constant for all soil layers and a 50 per cent variation of the reference model was considered to obtain three cases: 0.015, 0.03 (reference case), and 0.045.

Figure 17 shows the velocity at the surface of the ground in the frequency domain at the considered soil damping ratios. As observed in Fig. 13, higher frequency components attenuate faster than lower frequency components as the as the distance from the tunnel axis increases. Take the peak value at 3.1 Hz for example, the larger damping results in a decrease of 26.09, 30.56, and 34.33 per cent at the points 0, 20, and 40 m away from tunnel axis, respectively; the smaller damping results in an increase of 15.22, 19.41, and 22.39 per cent at the points 0, 20, and 40 m away from tunnel axis, respectively. This means that the variation of the soil damping ratio has an increasing influence as the lateral distance away from the tunnel axis increases. Fig. 17
Velocity at the surface of the ground as a function variation of the soil damping ratio at (a) 0 m, (b) 20 m, and (c) 40 m away from the tunnel axis

Figure 18 shows the vibration levels created as a result of the variation of the soil damping ratio. The vibration levels in the tunnel do not seem to be affected by the variation of the soil damping ratio. In contrast the vibration levels at the surface of the ground are increasingly affected as the damping ratio increases and as the lateral distance away from the tunnel axis increases. The variation in the vibration level is less than 1 dB at the surface above the tunnel axis which increases to 5 dB at a distance of 50 m. Fig. 18
Comparison of the vibration level due to variation in the soil damping ratio (a) in the tunnel and (b) at the surface of the ground

sec.title: 6.5 Effect of dry and saturated soil
sec.p: Soil is a discontinuous material in that the pores of the solid grain can be saturated with water. A high viscous coupling prevents the relative motion between the fluid and solid phase in the low-frequency range of interest in most civil engineering applications. Thus, the soil can be modelled as a dry elastic medium, provided that the density (equivalent density of the soil and water mixture) and the incompressibility (higher Poisson's ratio) of the saturated soil are accounted for in the model. The density of fully saturated soil is given by (23) where ρs is the density of the solid grains, ρf is the density of the pore fluid, and n is the porosity. The longitudinal wave velocity cp and shear wave velocity cs of saturated soil in the low-frequency limit can be described as (24) where λs and μs are the Lamé coefficients of the dry soil, Kf is the bulk modulus of the pore fluid and is equal to 2.2 × 109 N/m2. The elastic modulus and Poisson's ratio of the saturated soil can be computed from cp and cs.

A dry soil (reference case) and a fully saturated soil case were investigated. The porosity of the fully saturated soil was taken to be 0.3 for all soil layers. The effects of the two cases on the vibration levels areshown in Fig. 19. It can be seen that the fully saturated soil has a larger extent of vibration reduction than the dry soil both in the tunnel and onthe surface of the ground except at the mid-point of girder, which is similar to the effect seen for a smaller soil elastic modulus. The reduction has a value of about 3 dB at the surface of the ground in this case. Fig. 19
Comparison of vibration level for dry and saturated soils (a) in the tunnel and (b) at the surface of the ground

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A fully coupled 3D multi-body finite element‐PML model was developed in this paper to study the ground vibrations created by a high-speed maglev train running in a tunnel. The interaction between the maglev train and guideway was modelled using a linear spring and damper system, which was accurate enough to allow the simulation of magnetic force considering the 10 mm airgap and its small variance in the high-speed maglev system. The maglev train was modeled using multiple rigid bodies, the guideway‐tunnel‐soil system was modelled using 3D finite elements and the unbounded domain of the soil was simulated by the PML boundary.

The vibration levels created by a maglev train running on a viaduct line were computed using this methodology. The computed results show a reasonable agreement with experimental data, which demonstrates the applicability of the proposed methodology. The summation of the velocity level for theone-third octave band was used to quantify the vibration induced by a maglev train running in a tunnel.

The following conclusions can be drawn from the presented parametric studies.
The vibration is only attenuated to a small extent when it is transferred from the girder support to the tunnel. This vibration could be further diminished by the addition of an elastic rubber pad.
An increase in the speed of the maglev train results in an increase in the vibration levels in the tunnel and on the surface of the ground.
The thickness of the tunnel lining does not significantly affect the observed vibration effects.
The vibration levels in the tunnel and ground surface are sensitive to the soil stiffness, and a softer soil results in higher vibration levels.
The soil damping ratio has a negligible influence on the vibration levels in the tunnel; however, it is more influential at the surface of the ground.
Dry soil has smaller vibration attenuation than saturated soil both in the tunnel and at the surface of the ground.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grants 11072150, 50875166, and 61073088), the State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Systems and Vibration under grant MSVMS 201107, and the Shanghai Science and Technology Committee under grant 09231203100.
